TextEquiv.Unicode: dishonour, shall by the judgement and
polver of God be surely shut in disho
nour, and corruption, and so be con
demned for ever to beare endlesse tor
mentes, and in death and corruption
shall neither die nor yet corrupt : that
even as on earth are found certayne
bodies that doe indure even in the
fire, so the cursed bodies of the wicked
shal not be worne out nor broken with
any torments whatsoever, for every
minute they shal receive new strength
to suffer , and so by continuall susfe
ring shall abide their deserved punish
ments for ever and ever and without
all end. For the Lorde in the Gospell
sayeth, They that have done evill
shall rise agayne to the resurreetion of
damnation, that is, to an induring &
everlasting damnation. And Daniel
before him sayde, And the multitude
of them that sleepe in the dust of the
earth shall awake, some to everlasting
life, and some to shame and perpetual
contempt.
And in the Gospell agayne, the Lord
sayeth: Their worme dieth not, and
their fire is not duenched. And the
very same wordes used Elay before
him in his 66. Chapter. Tee must
alwayes therefore have that saying
of the Lorde in our hearts, Jeare him
that can destroy both the body ethe
soule in hell. Thus much hitherto tou
ching the resurrection of the flesh.
The last Article of our belief, which
with good lucke shutteth up the rest, is
this, And life everlasting. Wee have
heard and understood that the foules
of men are immortall, and that our
bodies doe rise againe in the ende of
the worlde. Vee have confessed that
this is our beleefe. It followeth now
in the latter end of the Creede, whi
ther it is, that the immortal soule, and
body raised up again shal come. Ther

dishonour, shall by the judgement and polver of God be surely shut in disho nour, and corruption, and so be con demned for ever to beare endlesse tor mentes, and in death and corruption shall neither die nor yet corrupt : that even as on earth are found certayne bodies that doe indure even in the fire, so the cursed bodies of the wicked shal not be worne out nor broken with any torments whatsoever, for every minute they shal receive new strength to suffer , and so by continuall susfe ring shall abide their deserved punish ments for ever and ever and without all end. For the Lorde in the Gospell sayeth, They that have done evill shall rise agayne to the resurreetion of damnation, that is, to an induring & everlasting damnation. And Daniel before him sayde, And the multitude of them that sleepe in the dust of the earth shall awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and perpetual contempt. And in the Gospell agayne, the Lord sayeth: Their worme dieth not, and their fire is not duenched. And the very same wordes used Elay before him in his 66. Chapter. Tee must alwayes therefore have that saying of the Lorde in our hearts, Jeare him that can destroy both the body ethe soule in hell. Thus much hitherto tou ching the resurrection of the flesh. The last Article of our belief, which with good lucke shutteth up the rest, is this, And life everlasting. Wee have heard and understood that the foules of men are immortall, and that our bodies doe rise againe in the ende of the worlde. Vee have confessed that this is our beleefe. It followeth now in the latter end of the Creede, whi ther it is, that the immortal soule, and body raised up again shal come. Ther
fore in our confession we say: And life)
everlasting, that is, I believe that :
shall have life, and live for ever both
in body & soule. And that everlasting
nesse verily is perpetual & hath no end,
as a little before is proved out of the
holy Scriptures.
Moreover, the foules are made par
takers of this eternall life immediat
ly after they are departed out of the
bodies, as the Lord himselfe witnes
seth saying, Te that beleeveth in the
Sonne of GOD shall not come into
judgement, but hath escaped from
death to life. As for the bodies they
are buried and doe putrifie, and yet so
notwitstanding, that they shal not bee
without life for ever. But they shal
then at length be received into eter
nall life, when beeing raysed up, they
shall after: the time of judgement bee
caught into the ayre, there to meete
Christ that they may forever bee with
the Lorde. For then doe the foules re
turne Sit of heaven every one to his
owne hgdie, that the whole, perfect, &
fil man may live for ever both in soule
and body. For the soule of Christ dy
ing on the Crosse did out of hand de
part into Paradise, and the thirde
day after returned to the body, which
rose againe and ascended into heaven.
Even as therfore, eternal life came to
the head Christ, so shall it also come to
al and every membder of Christ,
Now, whereas Paul citing Clay,
sayth: what the eye hath not seene,
nor the eare hearde, nor hath at any
time come into the heart of man, that
hath the Lord prepared for them that
love him. I suppose verily if all were
sayd touching eternall life, that might
be spoken by al the men of al ages that
be throughly touched.
ever were or shall be, yet that scarcely
the very least part therof hath or shall

fore in our confession we say: And life) everlasting, that is, I believe that : shall have life, and live for ever both in body & soule. And that everlasting nesse verily is perpetual & hath no end, as a little before is proved out of the holy Scriptures. Moreover, the foules are made par takers of this eternall life immediat ly after they are departed out of the bodies, as the Lord himselfe witnes seth saying, Te that beleeveth in the Sonne of GOD shall not come into judgement, but hath escaped from death to life. As for the bodies they are buried and doe putrifie, and yet so notwitstanding, that they shal not bee without life for ever. But they shal then at length be received into eter nall life, when beeing raysed up, they shall after: the time of judgement bee caught into the ayre, there to meete Christ that they may forever bee with the Lorde. For then doe the foules re turne Sit of heaven every one to his owne hgdie, that the whole, perfect, & fil man may live for ever both in soule and body. For the soule of Christ dy ing on the Crosse did out of hand de part into Paradise, and the thirde day after returned to the body, which rose againe and ascended into heaven. Even as therfore, eternal life came to the head Christ, so shall it also come to al and every membder of Christ, Now, whereas Paul citing Clay, sayth: what the eye hath not seene, nor the eare hearde, nor hath at any time come into the heart of man, that hath the Lord prepared for them that love him. I suppose verily if all were sayd touching eternall life, that might be spoken by al the men of al ages that be throughly touched. ever were or shall be, yet that scarcely the very least part therof hath or shall
